Name: Land Facet Diversity
Description:
Land facets is a unique combinations of geophysical factors that stratify the landscape into discrete classes relevant to the needs of an analysis. Land-facet diversity represents the variety of land-facet types, which are landscape areas classified according to landform, elevation, HLI, and soil order. Higher values indicate a greater nearby variety of land facets (combinations of elevation, HLI, landforms, and soil orders).

Value Interpretation:

Higher values indicate a greater nearby variety of land facets (combinations of elevation, HLI, landforms, and soil orders).

Reference:

Carroll, C., T. Wang, D. R. Roberts, J. L. Michalak, J. J. Lawler, S. E. Nielsen, D. Stralberg, A. Hamann, and B. H. McRae. 2017. Scale-dependent complementarity of climatic velocity and environmental diversity for identifying priority areas for conservation under climate change. Global Change Biology 23:4508â€“4520.

Name: Karst Potential Areas
Description:
An interpretation of bedrock geology, topography and other sources of information that shows the potential for karst formations. The polygons intended to highlight where karst areas may occur and to estimate the likely intensity of karst development in these areas. We included karst because it supports rare plant assemblages [1] and has conservation status in British Columbia planning decisions [2].

Reference:

Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development, BC, Canada, aquired date 2019, data from the British Columbia Geographic Data (https://catalogue.data.gov.bc.ca). [1] DellaSala, Dominick A., et al. "Red-Listed Ecosystem Status of Interior Wetbelt and Inland Temperate Rainforest of British Columbia, Canada." Land 10.8 (2021): 775. [2] Ministry of Forests Research Branch. Karst Inventory Standards and Vulnerability Assessment Procedures for British Columbia. 2003.
